awd_titl_txt: Synchronization, Collective Behavior and Spatiotemporal Dynamics in Chemical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program (CSDM-A) of the Chemistry Division, Professor Kenneth Showalter and his students are studying complex dynamical behavior in chemical systems to gain insights into new types of dynamical behavior in man-made and living systems. Developing an understanding of such behavior in experimental studies facilitates the development of mathematical model descriptions that are relevant to the behavior of certain living organisms as well as synthetic dynamical systems such as computer networks. Research on new states of synchronization and collective behavior will provide insights into basic dynamical behaviors pervasive in living systems. Research on propagating waves in precipitation systems will offer new mechanisms for chemical waves that rely on structural features of the medium, much like wave behavior found in many biological systems.


Networks of coupled chemical oscillators will be investigated in laboratory experiments and computational simulations. The recently discovered chimera state, in which populations of synchronized and unsynchronized oscillators coexist, will be further investigated, with the focus on the spiral chimera state in two-dimensional arrays of coupled oscillators. Further experimental investigations of phase-lag synchronization in networks of coupled chemical oscillators will also be carried out with two-dimensional oscillator arrays, which will allow a wide variety of network topologies and coupling schemes. Theoretically predicted echo phenomena will be investigated in populations of coupled chemical oscillators. Two-dimensional arrays of chemical oscillators will permit sufficiently large populations to allow the detection and characterization of echo behavior. New configurations and examples of propagating precipitation waves will be investigated. Open-reactor configurations will be developed for studies of propagating waves in redissolution precipitation bands based on the amphoteric sodium hydroxide-aluminum chloride system. Unstable spiral wave behavior leading to turbulence-like dynamics will be investigated as well as wave stacking, where waves collide with the waves ahead of them. Further development of a general three-dimensional computational model for propagating precipitation waves will be carried out as well as extending the model to describe wave behavior in open reactor configurations

por.por_cntn:
Chemical systems have played an important role in the development of research on complex dynamical systems, since even complicated chemical systems, such as the Belousov-Zhabotinsky (BZ) reaction, are relatively straightforward to characterize. This is due to the fact that the state variables are simple concentrations and the governing equations can be developed from well-understood chemical kinetics and transport processes. Hence, studies of complex dynamics in chemical model systems can yield valuable insights into the surprisingly similar dynamics seen in biological systems.

Our studies of chemical model systems over the award period have yielded significant advances in understanding synchronization behavior in populations of oscillators. Recently, extensive research activity has focused on a surprising dynamical behavior in which synchronized and unsynchronized oscillators coexist, named the chimera state after the Greek mythological creature. In a planar 2D configuration, spiral wave chimeras are exhibited that have a core of asynchronous oscillators.

The spiral wave chimera is a particularly remarkable chimera state, in which an ordered spiral wave rotates around a core consisting of asynchronous oscillators. Spiral wave chimeras were theoretically predicted in 2004 and have since been theoretically studied in a variety of dynamical systems. During the grant period, we reported the first experimental characterization of spiral wave chimera states. We achieved this using large populations of coupled BZ chemical micro-oscillators arranged in a two-dimensional array. We also describe previously unreported spatiotemporal dynamics, including growth and splitting of the cores, as well as the transition from chimera to phase-cluster behavior. The discrete micro-oscillators are catalyst-loaded ion-exchange beads in catalyst-free BZ solution. The experimental setup, shown in Fig. 1(a), allows the current state of each micro-oscillator to be monitored by using a camera to record its fluorescence intensity, which is linearly proportional to the concentration of the reduced form of the ruthenium catalyst. The light intensity projected onto each oscillator is controlled using a spatial light modulator. A spiral wave chimera exhibiting the coexistence of coherent and incoherent oscillators is shown in Fig. 1(b)-1(d), with a snapshot of the gray values and color coded phase and period of each oscillator, respectively. The local order parameter is shown in Fig. 1(e), which illustrates the ordered spiral wave and the disordered spiral wave core. Our studies suggest that the spiral wave chimeras observed in the BZ system are likely to be found in a variety of other systems with the common properties of long-range interactions and nearly immediate firing following a perturbation.

Our research program in Nonlinear Chemical Dynamics plays an important role in the educational infrastructure of West Virginia University. Two students (including one underrepresented minority) have graduated with Ph.D. degrees in chemistry and one with an M.S. degree during the grant award period. We typically have at least one undergraduate student with an interest in nonlinear dynamics working in the laboratory during the academic year.

During the grant period, the PI was involved in service to WVU at the department, college and university levels and to the broader chemistry and physics communities at the national and international levels. The PI is the primary organizer of the Bennett Careers for Chemists Program that is held annually at WVU. This is a highly successful program designed to inform high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in chemistry of the many career opportunities available to them.

The PI co-organized the workshop "Multistability and Tipping: From Mathematics and Physics to Climate and Brain," held at the Max Planck Institute for Physics of Complex Systems (MPIPKS) in Dresden, Germany, October 4-8, 2016. The PI is a founding director of the School on Hands-On Research in Complex Systems, which was developed to promote science and science education in the developing world. It has become an ongoing annual two-week school at the International Centre for Theoretical Physics (ICTP) in Trieste, Italy, and the PI and Co-PI taught laboratory classes on coupled chemical oscillators in 2017 and 2018, respectively. The PI co-organized the workshop "Chimera States: From Theory and Experiments to Technology and Living Systems" to be held May 4-8, 2020, at the Max Planck Institute for Physics of Complex Systems (MPIPKS) in Dresden, Germany. The workshop was to feature 22 invited speakers from 11 different countries and a similar number of contributed talks. The MPIPKS rescheduled the workshop to May 16-20, 2022.

During the grant period, the PI and Co-PI served on the search committee for Chair of the Department of Chemistry, WVU. The PI also served as Chair of the search committee for Chair of the Department of Physics and Astronomy, WVU. The PI served as the elected Councilor of the Northern West Virginia Local Section of the American Chemical Society, which plays an important role in supporting chemistry programs in area colleges and high schools.
